pr_title: BLUEBUTTON-1573: Configure tracing and transaction names in New Relic

timeline.message:
Set operation canonical name in logs and New Relic.

Particularly for New Relic, this should allow us to make meaningful
measurements and comparisons of the performance of various operations.

BLUEBUTTON-1573

Configure detailed New Relic tracing.

This tells New Relic to break out transaction traces in more detail,
allowing us a better picture of what time is actually being spent on.

timeline.bodyText: To check my understanding this will log an operation of V1_COVERAGE twice. Once here and once in RequestResponseLoggingFilter
timeline.author: whytheplatypus

replies.bodyText:
Sort of. The RequestResponseLoggingFilter sets the default operation name at the start of each request to new Operation(Operation.Endpoint.OTHER). That gets set in the MDC, which is a single-valued Map.
Any handler/endpoint that wants to customize that can override it by creating a more specific Operation and calling publishOperationName() on it. That publish call overrides the default value in the MDC.
That make sense?
replies.author: karlmdavis

replies.bodyText:
it's using matchByHttpUri in the default, so I'd expect that to return V1_COVERAGE since it's a listed endpoint?
The default logic goes from requestHttpUri -> Endpoint enum -> requestHttpUri
replies.author: whytheplatypus

replies.bodyText:
Ahh, yes -- had forgotten about the matching. That's correct, though it won't have the params -- just the operation name.
Regardless, it won't get logged twice -- the access log is only written to once per response, in gov.cms.bfd.server.war.RequestResponseLoggingFilter.addToHttpAccessLog().
(Being pedantic: note that I said it only gets logged to the access log once. The other message/event log will also include whichever values the MDC happens to have at the time of any logging event. It doesn't particularly matter and there's not a lot we can do about it, given SLF4J's API -- short of replacing the MDC entirely, ourselves, which feels like a bad idea.)
replies.author: karlmdavis
